data.vignette: A 78-year-old man with end-stage COPD and heart failure is on home hospice with a clear comfort-focused plan. Over the last day he has developed severe air hunger and panic despite oxygen, a fan, and low-dose oral morphine; he is now too breathless to speak in full sentences and is intermittently drowsy. The hospice physician believes escalating to a continuous opioid infusion and adding a sedating medication could reliably relieve his distress, but it would likely deepen sedation and may worsen carbon dioxide retention, raising concern about potentially shortening life. The bedside nurse reports the family is frightened that “stronger meds will stop his breathing,” yet they also cannot bear watching him struggle. The physician must decide how aggressively to treat his refractory symptoms tonight.
data.choice_1: Escalate to continuous opioid therapy (and, if needed, sedation) to prioritize rapid relief of dyspnea and distress, accepting the possibility of deeper sedation and respiratory worsening.
data.choice_2: Continue only cautious, small dose adjustments and non-drug measures to avoid iatrogenic respiratory suppression, accepting that his dyspnea and distress may remain poorly controlled.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove wording that makes one option sound predictably effective or the other predictably ineffective. For example, change “could reliably relieve his distress” to “may relieve his distress,” and change Choice 2 from “accepting that his dyspnea and distress may remain poorly controlled” to “accepting that relief may be slower or incomplete.” Also avoid implying a causal link to hastened death as a near-expected outcome; rephrase “raising concern about potentially shortening life” to “with uncertain risk of worsening hypercapnia and deeper sedation.”

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Reduce the sense that escalation is the obvious ‘right’ answer given the already ‘clear comfort-focused plan.’ To keep both options ethically/clinically defensible, add a sentence that the patient previously expressed a wish to stay as awake/interactive as possible (or declined heavy sedation) OR that prior opioid escalation caused troubling somnolence/delirium. Alternatively, soften “clear comfort-focused plan” to “generally comfort-focused goals,” leaving room for competing priorities.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the sense that Choice 1 is the clinically obvious/standard answer by adding a concrete competing value that Choice 2 preserves (e.g., the patient previously stated he wants to remain awake/able to recognize family, or he is awaiting an out-of-town child to arrive tomorrow and he valued being alert). Explicitly state that deeper sedation would likely prevent meaningful interaction and could preclude honoring those previously expressed preferences. Reframe the clinical language so neither option is described as reliably effective or as merely 'cautious'/'non-drug'—e.g., describe Choice 2 as prioritizing wakefulness/communication and avoiding medication-induced delirium while accepting ongoing distress, and describe Choice 1 as prioritizing symptom relief while accepting loss of consciousness/interaction and possible life-shortening concern. Consider clarifying that prognosis is hours–days but not clearly imminent, so the tradeoff feels less predetermined.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace emotive or leading phrasing with neutral clinical language: change “cannot bear watching him struggle” to “reports distress at witnessing his dyspnea.” Remove/soften claims implying one option is clearly superior, e.g., change “could reliably relieve his distress” to “is expected to relieve his distress.” Consider balancing language by adding a neutral sentence acknowledging the alternative’s rationale (e.g., concern about unintended respiratory depression) without framing either as the ‘right’ choice.

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Increase novelty and reduce ‘textbook’ palliative-sedation framing by adding one or two case-specific but de-identified clinical constraints that shape the dilemma (e.g., an existing advance directive that addresses sedation, prior adverse reaction to benzodiazepines, limited overnight access to infusion pump/monitoring, or a documented prior conversation about wanting to remain awake for family). Avoid familiar stock phrasing like “potentially shortening life”; rephrase to “concern that higher doses could contribute to further somnolence and ventilatory compromise in a patient with chronic hypercapnia.”

data.vignette: You are the overnight hospitalist covering a 68-year-old man with end-stage COPD and chronic CO2 retention who was admitted for worsening dyspnea. He is DNR/DNI and has generally comfort-focused goals, but in a documented conversation earlier this week he said he wanted to stay awake enough to recognize family and asked to avoid “being knocked out” if possible. Despite oxygen, nebulizers, and intermittent low-dose opioids, he is now visibly air-hungry and anxious; higher opioid doses earlier today led to troubling somnolence and confusion. His spouse reports distress at witnessing his labored breathing and requests that you “give whatever it takes” so he is not struggling. The unit has limited overnight staffing and no capacity for continuous capnography; an infusion pump can be started but close titration and monitoring will be challenging until morning. Prognosis is thought to be hours to days, but not clearly imminent. You must decide how to respond tonight.
data.choice_1: Escalate symptom management now with higher-dose opioids and/or sedating medications aimed at rapid relief of dyspnea and anxiety, accepting that he will likely become minimally interactive and that there is uncertain risk of worsening hypercapnia and deeper sedation.
data.choice_2: Continue lower-dose, stepwise symptom measures overnight (e.g., small PRN opioid doses, nonpharmacologic coaching, and anxiolysis only if needed), prioritizing wakefulness and the patient’s stated preference to remain interactive, accepting that relief may be slower or incomplete.

choice_1.choice: Escalate symptom management now with higher-dose opioids and/or sedating medications aimed at rapid relief of dyspnea and anxiety, accepting that he will likely become minimally interactive and that there is uncertain risk of worsening hypercapnia and deeper sedation.

choice_2.choice: Continue lower-dose, stepwise symptom measures overnight (e.g., small PRN opioid doses, nonpharmacologic coaching, and anxiolysis only if needed), prioritizing wakefulness and the patient’s stated preference to remain interactive, accepting that relief may be slower or incomplete.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the patient's autonomy more explicit by indicating his current decisional capacity and/or a clear prior documented preference to remain awake; tighten the binary by making Choice 1 a planned escalation to continuous infusion/rapid sedation for immediate relief vs Choice 2 a monitored, incremental approach explicitly prioritizing wakefulness. Clarify the clinical risk/monitoring constraints (hypercapnia, limited staffing/no capnography) to foreground nonmaleficence and justice/resource limitations, and specify that prognosis is hours–days to keep the urgency realistic.

Make the patient's prior expressed preference about remaining awake more specific (e.g., acceptable trade-off between alertness and dyspnea relief) and clarify his current decision-making capacity. Explicitly frame Choice 1 as proportional palliative sedation with clear intent and monitoring limits, and Choice 2 as honoring autonomy with risk of ongoing distress. Briefly note staffing/monitoring constraints to highlight nonmaleficence and justice (safety/resource limits).

data.vignette:
A 68-year-old man with end-stage COPD and chronic CO₂ retention (baseline pCO₂ ~70 mmHg) is admitted to a small community hospital with a severe exacerbation. He is DNR/DNI per a signed POLST. Despite maximal bronchodilators, steroids, high-flow nasal cannula, and carefully titrated opioids, he has refractory dyspnea with visible air hunger. A palliative care consultant estimates his prognosis is hours to days.

He is awake, oriented, and demonstrates decisional capacity by consistently stating his goals and accurately repeating back the trade-offs of sedation. Earlier that day, he documented in the chart: “Prioritize comfort, but I want to stay awake if possible to speak with my daughter; if my breathing distress becomes unbearable, I accept being made sleepy even if I cannot wake up again.” He reiterates now: “Please try to keep me awake until she gets here—unless I can’t stand it.”

It is overnight with limited staffing (one RN covering multiple patients). The ward has pulse oximetry but no continuous capnography, and no ICU beds are available. The team must choose an approach to manage his distress while considering safety and resource constraints.

choice_1.choice: Start proportional palliative sedation now for rapid symptom relief: give an opioid bolus and begin a continuous benzodiazepine infusion (with planned escalation to deep, continuous sedation if needed), accepting likely loss of wakefulness and increased risk of worsening hypercapnia/respiratory depression in the setting of limited respiratory monitoring.

choice_2.choice: Honor his stated wish to remain awake as long as possible: continue opioids with slow, stepwise titration; use nonpharmacologic measures (fan, positioning); offer only intermittent low-dose anxiolysis while he remains interactive; perform frequent bedside reassessments and coaching, with a plan to transition to continuous sedation only if he requests it or distress becomes intolerable.
